tossups.question: Ibn Battuta chose to spend the night on his ship rather than sleep in the city of Zayla in this modern country, as the stench of fish and camel blood was too much to bear. Cinnamon was brought to the city of Mosylon in this modern country before being transported to the Roman Empire. Yusuf al-Kawneyn was an Islamic scholar from this modern country who is credited with bringing Islam to the Maldives. The Ottomans allied with the (*) Ajuran Sultanate based in this modern country to curtail Portuguese influence in the western Indian Ocean. This modern country is the [emphasize] southernmost candidate for the location of the land of Punt referenced in ancient Egyptian sources. For 10 points, identify this modern country whose capital of Mogadishu rose to prominence in the Medieval period.

Notorious con man Monroe Edwards smuggled slaves from this modern country into the Republic of Texas by claiming that they were indentured servants with 99-year contracts. Ambrosio José Gonzales, a citizen of this modern country, supported American interests there and served as a general in the Confederate Army. The cessation of US support in a rebellion in this modern country was promoted by Manuel Urrutia Lleó. In what many locals thought was a coverup, (*)  Charles Magoon ordered the removal of the wreckage of a ship from the harbor of this modern country’s capital. This modern country’s current flag was designed in part by a man who tried to forcibly make it join the US, Narciso López. For 10 points, name this country that lies only about 100 miles south of Florida with a capital of Havana.

The southern reaches of this mountain range has been given the contested appellation of the “Country of Towns” for the several fortified Bronze Age settlements found in the area. The existence of the Classical “Riphean Mountains” was validated by the writings of Sigismund von Herberstein on this mountain range. A steel-producing town in this mountain range was modeled after Gary, Indiana. A route crossing this mountain range using a series of rivers and portages began at the town of Cherdyn until it was eventually supplanted by a path blazed by (*) Artemy Babinov. The Stroganov family funded a military expedition east of this mountain range, leading to Yermak’s conquest of the Khanate of Sibir. For 10 points, name this Russian mountain range, the conventional northern division between Europe and Asia.

A 1932 assassination attempt on a holder of this position also targeted Charlie Chaplin, but he was at an event with that holder of this position’s son when the attempt happened. A holder of this position committed suicide after refusing to cooperate with Bonner Feller’s “Operation Blacklist” and had earlier arranged secret negotiations with Joseph Grew. That holder of this position led the “New Order Movement” and attempted to institute one-party rule through his (*) Imperial Aid Association. Earlier, one of these people were assassinated in the May 15 incident, and many of those assassins had earlier been associated with the League of Blood. Members of the “Righteous Army” assassinated two former holders of this position in the February 26 incident. A holder of this position resigned after the fall of Saipan and was hanged in 1948 after being found guilty of war crimes by the International Military Tribunal for the Far East. For 10 points, name this position which was once held by Hideki Tojo.
tossups.answer: Prime Minister of Japan (accept Japanese Prime Minister)

tossups.question: Descriptive answer acceptable The act of amending this document was called “adding to the rafters”. This document gives women the right to confirm or deny the inheritance of certain political offices, symbolized with their control over strings of shells. This document permits the occasional granting of an advisory office to worthy people interested in governance; such people were likened to newly-sprung pine trees. Four joined white squares with a white pine in the middle represents the unity this document codified and was originally depicted on a belt made of (*) wampum. Known as the Great Law of Peace, this document was the culmination of the work of the Peacemaker and granted the centrally-located Onondaga the title “Keepers of the Fire”. For 10 points, identify this document, which directed the governance of a confederation of Native American tribes in upstate New York.
tossups.answer: Great Law of Peace of the Iroquois League (accept descriptive answers along the lines of the Iroquois constitution; accept Gayanashagowa; accept Haudenosaunee in place of “Iroquois”)

tossups.question: Immense Nazi demands of wine from this region led to one of its major producers walling up reserves of its 1928 vintage, a well-known favorite of Winston Churchill. Frustrated with the onset of the Phylloxera epidemic and the importation of grapes from other regions, wine producers in this region rioted in 1911, burning much of the town of Aÿ (ah-EE). The founder of a famous wine producer in this region served as mayor of Paris when it was liberated from Nazi rule. Breaking from the trend in the 19th century for wines from this region to be sweet, producer (*) Perrier-Jouët produced a dry wine that critics called brut (“brute”) for its perceived severity. Though he strove to remove the best-known quality of wines from this region, they grew in quality as innovations in pruning, harvesting, and pressing were pioneered by Dom Pérignon. For 10 points, name this French region that has become synonymous with sparkling wine.

From 1453 on, the Ghisolfi family ruled the Taman Peninsula on behalf of an institution in this industry. A medieval writer connected the city of Cahors to Sodom due to its heavy engagement in this industry. After the condemnation of commendas, the use of a contractum trinius could be used to circumvent restrictions on this industry. Lillian Randall suggested that the Lombards were depicted as snails in medieval manuscripts for participating in this industry. Unfavorable business forced by the English monarchy and mismanagement by (*) Tommaso Portinari were factors in the decline of the London and Bruges branches of an institution in this industry. Many Jews were employed in this industry because of Biblical prohibitions of usury. For 10 points, identify this industry whose modern form was developed by the likes of the Medici’s in late medieval and Renaissance Italy.

Shortly after abandoning Christianity, a man of this ethnic group was unharmed after being locked in a cage with a tiger for preaching the Ayyavazhi religion he founded. A temple built by this people was legendarily rebuilt at the urging of Gangadevi, who chronicled the overthrow of a Muslim power established by Jalauddin Ahsan Khan by her husband Kumara Kampana. An author of this people deified their language in one poem, claiming that it toured its earthly domains through the rulers of three dynasties of this people known as the mūvēntar, or (*) “three crowned kings”. The writings of the Nayanars and the Alvars, poet-saints of this people, led to the creation of the bhakti movement. The folklore of this people claims that three meetings of poets resulted in their earliest sangam literature. The ancient Meenakshi Temple lies at the center of this people’s cultural center of Madurai. For 10 points, identify this people whose name precedes “Nadu” in the name of a South Indian state.

Two mountains called the “Breasts of the North” were divinely brought closer together so that this ruler could more easily fortify the pass between them. After falling behind during a campaign to assist an aging friend, this ruler stole fire from the camp of the opposing Arabians to raise his soldiers’ spirits. Because they had no chalk, a city founded by this man was supposedly laid out using barley, which was quickly eaten by birds, portending the prosperity of the city. The Qur’anic story of (*) Dhul-Qarnayn (thool-“car-nine”) constructing a wall to protect against Gog and Magog is believed to have arisen from mythologized accounts of this ruler. This  ruler was supposedly born after the womb of his mother Olympias was struck by a lightning bolt from Zeus. According to Plutarch, this man dreamed of a satyr during a siege, which his seers deemed meant “sa Tyros”, or “Tyre is yours”. For 10 points, name this Macedonian ruler who conquered the Achaemenid Empire.
tossups.answer: Alexander the Great (accept Alexander III of Macedon)

tossups.question: An expedition sent out by a leader of this name apocryphally found a land whose residents’ ages changed based on how far up a certain hill they stood. That ruler of this name was supposedly conceived when a princess swallowed a jewel shot into her compound on an arrow by his father. Jacinto Canek (ha-SEEN-toe kah-NAKE) styled himself a “little” ruler of this name during his 1761 rebellion. The most famous account of the death of a ruler of this name claims that he was killed by (*) stones thrown by his subjects after trying to convince them to make peace with an invading force. Depictions of a god with black skin and the late date, and likely biased nature, of existing accounts make it unlikely that a ruler of this name perceived a Spanish hidalgo as a returning Queztalcoatl. For 10 points, what is this name held by the ruler of the Aztecs upon Cortés’ arrival in Mexico?
tossups.answer: Moctezuma (accept Montezuma, Moteuczoma, Motecuhzoma, Motēuczōmah, Muteczuma, Huēhuemotēuczōma)

tossups.question: Specific term required Quentin Skradec likened William McGuffey to Minerva in the “pantheon of American capitalism and [this idea]”. Pope Leo XIII wrote the letter Testem benevolentiae nostrae in response to the growth of this idea in the Catholic Church in America. Louis Henkin wrote that this idea promoted a “flying buttress mentality” that was attached to, but did not support, human rights. This idea was called a “heresy” for denying the universality of Marxist history by (*) Joseph Stalin. Louis Hartz argued that this idea developed because the US did not have feudalism. Though not the origin of the common name for this idea, John Winthrop expressed it through calling the Massachusetts Bay Colony a “city upon a hill”. For 10 points, what is this idea that America has a unique and privileged moral and diplomatic position on the world stage?

Though not directly a part of this agreement, Russian interests were considered by it due to the findings of the De Bunsen Committee. Erle Richards’ “P-memo” advocated for annulling this agreement, in line with the policies laid out in the most famous correspondence of Henry McMahon. One party to this agreement issued the Bassett Letter to reassure an ally of their territorial aspirations after this agreement was made public in the newspapers Pravda and Izvestia; that ally was (*) Hussein bin Ali. The ideas put forward in this agreement were furthered at the San Remo Conference, where it was decided that three Class “A” territories would be given to the involved parties. Widely blamed for the political instability of the Middle East during the last century, for 10 points, what was this 1916 agreement in which the UK and France planned the partition of the Ottoman Empire following WWI?

A turn of the twentieth century nationalist movement composed of people of this ethnic group described them as the “children of the three zhuz”. Girei and Zhanibek founded and co-ruled a state named after this ethnic group, and later toppled their former Shaybanid master Abu’l-Khair Khan. This ethnic group’s traditional law system, or adat, was considered in the legal reforms of Mikhail Speransky. The Alash Autonomy was a short-lived state formed by members of this ethnic group governed from (*) Semey until conquered in 1920 by the Red Army. Often contested with Russia, the “Inner Side” was the name this ethnic group gave to the land west of the Ural River. For 10 points, what is this ethnic group, whose namesake country recently renamed its planned capital city of Astana to Nursultan?

Anthropologist Peter Gow has critiqued the tendency of recent historiography of these processes to label the concept of duthchas (TU-khas)*, held by those affected, as “almost untranslatable”. Patrick Sellar was acquitted of homicide for the death of a woman caused by the arson he committed to further these processes. These processes destroyed the power of tacksmen. These processes coincided with a decline in the traditional famine occupation of kelp harvesting. These processes were legally outlawed by the (*) Crofters’ Act of 1886. In a reaction against these processes, residents of Strathrusdale drove 6,000 livestock off their land in 1792, the “Year of the Sheep”. For 10 points, what were these evictions of people from the northern portion of Britain throughout the 18th and 19th centuries, largely to allow for the expansion of sheep grazing?
tossups.answer: Highland Clearances (prompt on “enclosure” with “Of which region?”, prompt again if given “Scotland”)

tossups.question: Finding the “Kingdom of Beach” was a goal of a man known for exploring this modern country, who is now the namesake of a body of water to the east of this country sometimes called the Ditch. Peter Mühlhäusler has proposed that the word for “turtle” in languages like Ngarluma and Karriera is evidence for Portuguese sailors being the first Europeans to reach this modern country. The first confirmed European contact with this country was made by the crew of the Duyfken (dayf-ken). Early European settlement in the west of this modern country centered around the (*) Swan River Colony. William Landsborough crossed this country from north to south in an attempt to find traces of an earlier expedition traveling the other way led by Burke and Wills. This modern country was first circumnavigated by Matthew Flinders. For 10 points, what is this country, which takes its name from the Latin for “south”?

A leader of this state won the Battle of Mari and ravaged the cities of Mamistra, Adana, and Tarsus in Cilician Armenia. While serving this dynasty, Ibn Khaldun held a historic series of meetings with Tamurlane outside Damascus. Barquq took control of this state after a period of 40 years of nominal rule by the descendants of Al-Nasir Muhammad. While serving as a general for [emphasize] another state, a future leader of this state captured a monarch who was ransomed for 400,000 dinars following the Battle of (*) Al Mansurah. This state is broken by Western historians into “Baḥrī" and "Burjī" periods, while historians in the Muslim world name those periods the “Circassian” and “Turkish” periods, respectively. This state’s leaders included Qutuz and Baibars, who won against Kitbuqa and the Ilkhanate at Ayn Jalut. For 10 points, name this Egyptian state which succeeded the Ayyubids, named after an Arabic designation for slaves.

During the height of Athenian power in the 5th century BC, obstructing the import of this commodity was punishable by death. Hadrian recruited the Vulpes, a secret service, from men who worked with this commodity. In Athens, sitones were specialized traders in this commodity, which was regulated by sitophylakes. By the advent of the latifundia owned by senators, this commodity had become unprofitable to source from Italy, which relied on imports instead. Puclher abolished a form of distribution of this commodity in the late Roman Republic called the (*) frumentatio. Around a third of the early Roman Empire state’s revenues were spent on providing a product made with this commodity to its citizens, called the annona. Because it dedicated most of its arable land to growing olives, ancient Athens heavily relied on large amounts of this commodity imported from southern Russia, Ukraine, and Pontus. For 10 points, identify this staple crop grown on the Nile River that, along with wine and olives, made up the majority of the Roman diet.
tossups.answer: wheat (accept grain; prompt on “bread” or “flour” by asking what it was made with)

tossups.question: Carl Peters forced villagers in this colony to meet cotton-growing quotas, and Chief Mkwawa of the Hehe people resisted this colony’s expansion. A rebellion in this colony was led by a medium named Bokero and was named after the mixture of water, castor oil and bullets given by Bokero to his followers to protect against bullets. The Abushiri revolt was suppressed in this colony, which was ceded land that belonged to Khalifah bin Said. During a battle in this colony, units of the Indian Expeditionary Force under the command of Arthur Aitken were attacked by (*) bees during the Battle of Tanga, and this colony had earlier seen the Maji-Maji rebellion. General Lettow-Vorbeck led Askari troops in a guerilla campaign in this colony during World War I, after which it was partitioned by Portugal, Belgium and Britain. For 10 points, name this German colony whose land area included present-day Burundi, Rwanda, and mainland Tanzania.
tossups.answer: German East Africa (accept just East Africa after “German colony” is read; prompt on “Tanganyika”; do not accept or prompt on “German South-West Africa”)

tossups.question: In the Supreme Court Case Field v. Clark, the provisions of this tariff were found to not violate the nondelegation doctrine. Douglas Irwin has studied how this tariff “promoted infant industries” such as the tinplate industry. This tariff’s “reciprocity provision” permitted the president to match foreign rate hikes on industries such as coffee and tea. The architect of this tariff, known as the “Napoleon of Protection”, had earlier opposed the election of Joseph (*) Foraker to a third term as governor. This tariff eliminated the preferential status given to sugar imported from Hawaii. The Wilson-Gorman Tariff adjusted the rates set by this tariff, which raised average import duties to 49%. For 10 points, name this tariff whose namesake architect was president during the Spanish-American War.

In both the songs “Buffalo” and “Tamale”, Tyler the Creator claims that he’s “back like” this person. The 2020 song “Yikes” by Nikki Minaj sparked controversy after supposedly disrespecting this person. A song named after this person led to a long-running trial between this person and LaFace records. That song mentions a woman who tells its artists, “you only funky as your last cut / You focus on the past your ass'll be a has what,” and has a chorus that begins, “Ah ha, hush that fuss”. In a Cyhi the Prynce verse on the Kanye West song “So Appalled”, this person is paired with Ralph Abernathy. This person titles a 1998 song by (*) OutKast off their album Aquemini. A 2002 CBS television movie about this person’s “story” features Angela Bassett playing this person. For 10 points, name this civil rights pioneer whose refusal to give up her seat to a white passenger sparked the Montgomery Bus Boycott.
